questions.text: An 80 yrs male known case of diabetes and hypertension with a history of stroke presented to the casualty with irritability, confusion and increasing drowsiness. On examination, he looks dehydrated. the lab investigation is shown below: Hb 12.6 gm/dl Wbc Plt 9000/mm3 1.5 lakh Sodium 155meq/l Potassium 3.8meq/l Creatinine 1.4 What will be the next line of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Ryles tube insertion and free water through ryles tube

questions.correct_answer: A. Ryles tube insertion and free water through ryles tube
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ryles tube insertion and free water through ryles tube This patient has hypernatremia. Hypernatremia → increase in the plasma Na+ concentration to >145 mM Combined water and electrolyte deficit, with losses of H2O in excess of Na+. Probable causes in this patient (In view of dehydration ) Increased Insensible water loss Decreased water intake Osmotic diuresis due to high sugars (RBS not mentioned) Diabetes insipidus Hypernatremia should be corrected slowly to avoid cerebral oedema. Replace the calculated free water deficit over 48 h. Plasma Na+ concentration should be corrected by no more than 10 mM/d Treatment: Electrolyte-free water is administered by mouth or by nasogastric tube. ( Option A is correct) IV 5% dextrose (D5W) (Monitor RBS) If dehydrated/low volume à IV ½ NS or ¼ NS ( Options B and C are wrong)

Highyeild:

Differentiating between DI and osmotic diuresis as the cause of hypernatremia: The urine osmolar excretion rate is to be calculated Urine osmolar excretion rate = 24 hr urine output x urine osmolality

questions.text: A 32 yrs female who is 36 weeks pregnant presented with irritability confusion. Her lab investigation is shown below: Hb 10 gm/dl Wbc 9000/mm3 Plt 1.4 lakh Sodium 158meq/l Potassium 3.8meq/l Creatinine 1.4 LFT(liver function test) Normal What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gestational diabetes insipidus The above clinical scenario is of hypernatremia due to gestational diabetes insipidus. Hypernatremia is → increase in the plasma Na concentration to > 145 mmol The mortality is very high at 40-60% mostly due to underlying disease processes Gestational diabetes insipidus (DI ) A rare complication of pregnancy Develops in the third trimester Remits spontaneously 4–6 weeks Caused by excessive vasopressinase activity Vasopressinase is expressed by placental trophoblasts It metabolizes AVP → Reduced circulating AVP → Polyuria Treatment: DDAVP (desmopressin) Resistant to vasopressinase enzyme.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - characterized by renal resistance to AVP (vasopressin) Option B - Deficiency of AVP

questions.text: A 52 yrs male presented with lethargy, a confused state with irritable bowel syndrome and chronic diarrhoea. The lab investigations are shown below: Hb 12 gm/dl Wbc 8000/mm3 Plt 2.3 lakh Sodium 159meq/l Potassium 3.8meq/l Creatinine 1.9 Lft(liver function test) Normal What will be the line of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start i.v. fluids as 0.45% NaCl infusion and bolus doses

questions.correct_answer: A. Start i.v. fluids as 0.45% NaCl infusion and bolus doses
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Start i.v. fluids as 0.45% NaCl infusion and bolus doses This is a patient with IBS with fluid loss in the form of diarrhoea. This can lead to a state of combined salt and water loss If salt and water are equally lost → Hypovolemic hyponatremia If losses of water > Na → Hypernatremia Hyponatremia is defined as a plasma Na < 135mM Hypernatremia is defined as a plasma Na > 145Mm Lab report here shows Na = 159 → He has hypernatremia Treatment: (Free water deficit to be calculated and replaced) Electrolyte-free water is administered by mouth or by nasogastric tube. IV 5% dextrose (D5W) (Monitor RBS) If dehydrated / low volume → IV ½ NS or ¼ NS ( Options A is correct)

Highyeild:

The Free water deficit is the amount of free water a patient has lost. Calculated by: [(Na+ – 140)/140] × TBW Total-body water (TBW) → 50% of body weight in women and 60% in men.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . In hypovolemic hyponatremia Option: C . In severe symptomatic hyponatremia

questions.text: A 34 yrs male with bipolar disorder on treatment with lithium has now developed lethargy, irritability and polyuria. Hb 13 gm/dl Wbc 6000/mm3 Plt 2.3 lakh Sodium 160meq/l Potassium 3.5meq/l Creatinine 1.1 LFT(liver function test) Normal What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus This patient has developed Nephrogenic DI with hypernatremia secondary to lithium consumption. Characterized by renal resistance to AVP (vasopressin) Acute management: Replenishing ongoing free water losses By calculation of urinary electrolyte-free water clearance to estimate daily, ongoing loss of free water Chronic management: 1) Amiloride (ENaC inhibitor) 2.5 – 10 mg/d Decreases entry of lithium into principal cells à Decreases polyuria 2) Thiazides Induces hypovolemia and increases proximal tubular water reabsorption. 3) NSAIDs have been used Reduces the negative effect of intra-renal prostaglandins on urinary concentrating mechanisms

Highyeild:

Patients with central DI should respond to the administration of intravenous, intranasal, or oral DDAVP. Risk → NSAID-associated gastric and/or renal toxicity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Deficiency of AVP Option: C . Gestational diabetes insipidus (DI ) due to excessive vasopressinase activity in the third trimester and remits spontaneously 4–6 weeks postpartum.

Extraedge:

Lithium causes NDI by direct inhibition of renal glycogen synthase kinase 3 ( GSK3 ) GSK3 is required for the response of principal cells to AVP.

questions.text: A 23 yrs male came to the casualty with complaints of lethargy, increased frequency of urination and irritability. her lab findings are as follows: Hb 14 gm/dl Wbc 6400/mm3 Plt 2.3 lakh Sodium 156meq/l Potassium 3.5meq/l Creatinine 1.1 LFT(liver function test) Normal What will be the next important investigation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Urine osmolality and serum osmolality
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urine osmolality and serum osmolality This patient has presented with polyuria and hypernatremia. Laboratory investigations should include a measurement of Serum osmolality Urine osmolality Urine electrolytes. Serum osmolality > 295 mOsm/kg → Increase in circulating AVP and the excretion of low-volume urine High Urine osmolality (>800 mosm/kg) → Extrarenal losses Increased Insensible water loss GI loss Decreased water intake Increased sodium intake Low Urine osmolality (< 800 mosm/kg) → Renal losses Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic) Osmotic diuresis (glucose, mannitol, urea, etc)

Highyeild:

Points in favour of Extrarenal losses Increase in circulating AVP Urine volume < 500 ml/d Urine osmolality > 800 mOsm/kg (Maximally concentrated urine)

Extraedge:

Hypernatremic patients with NDI (Nephrogenic DI) Have high serum levels of AVP and copeptin. Low urine osmolality will fail to respond to DDAVP

questions.text: A 60 yrs male presented in the hospital with an acute confusional state and drowsiness. His lab investigation is as follows: Hb 16 gm/dl Wbc 6400/mm3 Plt 2.3 lakh Sodium 162meq/l Potassium 3.5meq/l Creatinine 1.1 LFT(liver function test) Normal Urine osmolality 620mosmol/dl What will be the next step for diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desmopressin test The above clinical scenario is of hypernatremia with low urine osmolality Urine osmolality in this patient is 620 mosm /kg Low Urine osmolality (< 800 mosm/kg) → Renal losses Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic) Osmotic diuresis (glucose, mannitol, urea, etc) Differentiation between nephrogenic and central causes of DI: Central DI Decreased level of AVP Decreased level of Copeptin Desmopressin test : Urine osmolality responding to DDAVP Nephrogenic DI (NDI) Increased level of AVP Increased level of Copeptin Desmopressin test : Low urine osmolality failing to respond to DDAVP Increasing by < 50% or < 150 mosm/kg from baseline

Highyeild:

Partial response to DDAVP: >50% rise in urine osmolality but < 800 mOsm / kg The level of circulating AVP will help differentiate NDI versus central DI

questions.text: A 40 yrs female came to the hospital with complaints of polyuria, lethargy and fatigue. On lab investigation, there is hypernatremia and decreased urine osmolality. She underwent a desmopressin test and there is no change in the urine osmolarity. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus The above clinical scenario is of hypernatremia with low urine osmolality Low Urine osmolality (< 800 mosm/kg) → Renal losses Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic) Osmotic diuresis (glucose, mannitol, urea, etc) Differentiation between nephrogenic and central causes of DI by Desmopressin test : Urine osmolality responding to DDAVP → Central DI Low urine osmolality failing to respond to DDAVP Increasing by < 50% or < 150 mosm/kg from baseline → NDI Hence this patient has nephrogenic DI

Highyeild:

In partial response to DDAVP levels of circulating AVP will help differentiate NDI versus central DI.

questions.text: A 28 yrs male came to the hospital in an acute confusional state with a history of falls. On a lab investigation, there was hypernatremia and a desmopressin test was advised. The urine osmolality increased post desmopressin , what will be the line of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral/iv/nasal desmopressin The clinical scenario is of hypernatremia secondary to Central DI (As there is a response to Desmopressin) The signs and symptoms of uncomplicated pituitary DI can be eliminated by treatment with (DDAVP) DDAVP ( Desmopressin) Synthetic analogue of AVP. Can be given by IV or SC injection, nasal inhalation, or oral. Dosage: 1–2 μg qd or bid by injection, 10–20 μg bid or tid by nasal spray or 100–400 μg bid or tid orally

Highyeild:

Acts selectively at V2 receptors →Increase urine concentration →Decrease urine flow in a dose-dependent 2. Resistant to degradation than is AVP 3.Three to fourfold longer duration of action

questions.text: A 35 yrs male came to the casualty with complaints of bipolar disorder on treatment with lithium, now complaining of polyuria, lethargy and polydipsia. What is the mechanism involved?

options.label: A
options.text: direct inhibition of glycogen kinase -3, (gsk-3), a kinase that is required for the response of the principal cell to AVP(vasopressin)

options.label: B
options.text: The entry of lithium through the amiloride-sensitive na channel Enac is required for the effect of the drug on the principal cell, such that combined therapy within lithium and amiloride can mitigate lithium-associated nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

options.label: C
options.text: Lithium causes chronic tubulointerstitial scarring and chronic kidney disease after prolonged therapy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above This patient has developed Nephrogenic DI with hypernatremia secondary to lithium consumption. Lithium causes NDI by multiple mechanisms : Direct inhibition of renal glycogen synthase kinase 3 ( GSK3 ) (GSK3 is required for the response of principal cells to AVP) The entry of lithium through ENaC (amiloride-sensitive Na+ channel) affects principal cells. Chronic tubulointerstitial scarring and CKD after prolonged therapy → Persistent NDI Acute management: Replenishing ongoing free water losses By calculation of urinary electrolyte-free water clearance to estimate daily, ongoing loss of free water Chronic management: 1) Amiloride (ENaC inhibitor) 5 – 10 mg/d Decreases entry of lithium into principal cells à Decreases polyuria 2) Thiazides Induces hypovolemia and increases proximal tubular water reabsorption. 3) NSAIDs have been used Reduces the negative effect of intra-renal prostaglandins on urinary concentrating mechanisms

Highyeild:

Lithium-induced chronic damage → Persistent NDI long after stopping the drug.

questions.text: A 20 yrs male came to the casualty with complaints of increased urine frequency, lethargy and fatigue. On lab investigation there is hypernatremia and decreased urine osmolality, in view of this desmopressin test was performed and there is no change in urine osmolality post-desmopressin test. What is the line of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiazide The clinical scenario is of hypernatremia secondary to Nephrogenic DI (As there is no response to Desmopressin) Acute management: Replenishing ongoing free water losses By calculation of urinary electrolyte-free water clearance to estimate daily, ongoing loss of free water Chronic management: 1) Thiazides (Option B is correct) Induces hypovolemia and increases proximal tubular water reabsorption. 2) NSAIDs have been used to reduce the negative effect of intra-renal prostaglandins on urinary concentrating mechanisms

Highyeild:

In lithium-induced NDI → Amiloride (ENaC inhibitor) 2.5 – 10 mg/d Decreases entry of lithium into principal cells à Decreases polyuria Patients with central DI should respond to the administration of intravenous, intranasal, or oral DDAVP (Option A is wrong) Risk → NSAID-associated gastric and/or renal toxicity.

questions.text: A 68 yrs female with a history of stroke, bedridden for the last 2 months, presented with irritability and an acute confusional state, what will be the line of treatment used for this pt? Hb 10gm/dl Wbc Plt 6400/mm3 2.3 lakh Sodium 162meq/l Potassium 3.5meq/l Creatinine 1.4

options.label: A
options.text: Ryles tube insertion and free water through Ryles tube

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above This patient has hypernatremia. Hypernatremia → increase in the plasma Na+ concentration to >145 mM Combined water and electrolyte deficit, with losses of H2O in excess of Na+. Probable causes in this patient (In view of bedridden status ) Increased Insensible water loss Decreased water intake Osmotic diuresis due to high sugars (RBS not mentioned) Diabetes insipidus Treatment: Electrolyte-free water is administered by mouth or by nasogastric tube. ( Option A is correct) IV 5% dextrose (D5W) (Monitor RBS) ( Option B is correct) If dehydrated/low volume → IV ½ NS or ¼ NS ( Option C is correct)

Highyeild:

Hypernatremia should be corrected slowly to avoid cerebral oedema. Replace the calculated free water deficit over 48 h . Plasma Na+ concentration should be corrected by =/< 10 mM/d

Extraedge:

Differentiating between DI and osmotic diuresis as the cause of hypernatremia: The urine osmolar excretion rate is to be calculated Urine osmolar excretion rate = 24 hr urine output x urine osmolality

questions.text: A 38-year-old male was admitted to ICU with a history of altered sensorium. His serum sodium level was found to be 106 meq/l. He was started on correction with 3% NaCl for the same. Subsequently, he developed dysphagia, dysarthria, and diplopia and subsequently developed quadriparesis. The MRI brain is shown below. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: It can also present as a “locked-in syndrome”

options.label: C
options.text: Other structures such as the cerebellum, lateral geniculate body, and thalamus can also be involved

options.label: D
options.text: Ataxia, mutism, and parkinsonism can also be the presentation of this condition

questions.correct_answer: A. Immediate thrombolysis should be done
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate thrombolysis should be done MRI Brain (FLAIR sequence) → Hyperintensities in the region of pons ODS (Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome) /CPM (Central pontine myelinolysis) The clinical scenario is of a hyponatremia with likely rapid correction leading to ODS. ODS (Mechanism) Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) Hypertonic stress in astrocytes within brain regions prone to ODS, leading to a) Generalized protein ubiquitination b) Endoplasmic reticulum stress due to activation of the unfolded protein response. 3. Disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.

Highyeild:

The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons. Clinically → Present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia Paraparesis or quadri-paresis Dysphagia Dysarthria Diplopia, A “locked-in syndrome” ( Option B is correct ) Loss of consciousness. Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in order of frequency: Lateral geniculate body Thalamus Putamen, and Cerebral cortex or sub-cortex. Clinical presentations vary with ataxia, mutism, parkinsonism, dystonia, and catatonia. (Option C is correct)

Extraedge:

Slow correction can be associated with ODS in patients with additional risk factors: Alcoholism Malnutrition Hypokalemia Liver transplantation.

questions.text: A 68 year old male approached a urologist with complaints of difficulty in passing urine and nocturia. He was found to have Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy and was posted for TURP surgery. 6 hours following the surgery he developed altered sensorium, irrelevant speech and lethargy. Subsequently, he had an episode of GTCS lasting 2 min and then had to be shifted to the ICU. What is the most likely cause for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyponatremia During the procedure of TURP, the irrigant likely used might have been Glycine Absorption of this hypotonic irrigation fluid → Dilutional hyponatremia Symptoms range from being asymptomatic to severe symptomatic hyponatremia with headache, anxiety, confusion to convulsions, coma and death. Treatment: Fluid restriction Potassium replacement (In coexisting hypokalemia) Increased solute intake (Oral salt / oral urea tabs) Loop diuretics such as furosemide can be used to eliminate excess fluid. Hypertonic saline → Only in severe symptomatic hyponatremia (impaired consciousness and convulsions)

Highyeild:

TURP Syndrome is related to the amount of fluid that enters the circulation via the blood vessels in the resection area.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . There are no features of sepsis in this case such as fever, warm peripheries, tachycardia etc. Option: B . Posterior circulation stroke will present with bulbar symptoms such as dysphagia, dysphonia, dysarthria or blindness. Option: D . Organic causes must be considered first rather than directly attributing to a psychiatric cause. Hyponatremia, which is a common complication in this clinical setting must be considered first.

Extraedge:

Demeclocycline can be used in patients whose Na levels do not increase in response to furosemide and salt tablets. However it can cause a reduction in GFR and/or direct renal toxicity.

questions.text: A 43 year old male, known case of IHD s/p PTCA to LAD, is admitted to the medical ward with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia. He is started on ceftriaxone and azithromycin for the same. He is hemodynamically stable. JVP is normal and there is no oedema. Laboratory investigations reveal a serum sodium level of 122 meq/l. Further, a workup done for evaluation of hyponatremia revealed the following Serum osmolarity-260 mosm/kg. Urine sodium -38 meq/l Serum potassium -3. 8 meq/l Urine osmolality 200 mmol/l All the following can be considered as a differential diagnosis in this condition except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic renal failure The above clinical scenario is of Euvolemic hyponatremia. Euvolemia is the state or condition of having the normal volume of blood or fluids in the body with the absence of oedema Mild increase in water content with an almost normal level of absorption of sodium à Euvolemic hyponatremia Euvolemic hyponatremia can occur in conditions listed below in the table. Correction occurs after correcting the underlying abnormality.

Highyeild:

SIADH is the most frequent cause of euvolemic hyponatremia This clinical scenario can be solved by following the flowchart which is shown below Now, this patient has no oedema, normal JVP-therefore he is euvolemic His urine sodium is >20. Therefore the differential diagnosis to be considered are Glucocorticoid deficiency Hypothyroidism Stress SIADH Renal failure will usually present as hypervolemic hyponatremia with a urinary sodium of >20. Other options a, b, c are all causes of euvolemic hyponatremia with a urine sodium of >20 meq/l

questions.text: A 54 year old male has been detected to have hyponatremia with serum sodium of 102 meq/l. He is to be started on a 3% NaCl infusion. What is the concentration of Sodium in this solution?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

513 mmol/l 513 mmol/l Lab reports s/o hyponatremia (102 mEq/L) Treatment with hypertonic saline is essential in severe and symptomatic patients. Treatment with hypertonic 3% saline 3% NS contains 513mM of Na and Cl. As an infusion : Increase plasma Na+ concentration by 1–2 mM/h to a total of 4–6 Mm As bolus : 100 mL of hypertonic saline rapidly improves both serum sodium and mental status. The compositions of common solutions are shown below table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Solute Plasma Crystalloids Normal Saline Ringer's Lactate Hartmann's Solution Plasma- Lyte Na+ 135-145 154 130 131 140 K+ 4.0-5.0 0 4.5 5 5 Ca2+ 2.2-2.6 0 2.7 4 0 Mg2+ 1.0-2.0 0 0 0 1.5 CI- 95-110 154 109 III 98 Acetate 0 0 0 0 27 Lactate 0.8-1.8 0 28 29 0 Gluconate 0 0 0 0 23 Bicarbonate 23-26 0 0 0 0 Osmolarity 291 308 280 279 294 Colloid 35-45 0 0 0 0 Osmolarity (mOsm/L); Colloid (g/L); All other solutes (mmol/L)

Highyeild:

Na+ deficit = 0.6 × body weight × (target plasma Na+ concentration – starting plasma Na+ concentration) Plasma Na+ concentration should be monitored every 2–4 h

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Normal saline contains 154mmol/l of sodium Option c-Ringers lactate contains 130 mmol/l of sodium Option: D. It is a distracting option

Extraedge:

3% NS bolus is more effective than infusion Type of respiratory failure seen: Hypercapnic respiratory failure

questions.text: A 48 year old male is admitted in the ICU with a history of Subarachnoid haemorrhage following RTA. On day 3 of the ICU stay he develops polyuria with a 24hr urine output of 4l/day. He is found to have signs of dehydration and orthostatic hypotension. His lab investigations are as follows Na+/K+/Cl- - 110/3. 8/102 Serum osmolality -260mosm/kg Urine osmolality- 300 mosm/kg Urine Na-50 meq/l BUN-28 mg/dl Serum Creatinine-0. 76mg/dl Serum uric acid -5.5mg/dl What is the LIKELY cause for hyponatremia in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cerebral salt wasting syndrome As per the clinical scenario, and lab reports, this patient has Hypovolemic hyponatremia A state of combined salt and water loss, leading to contraction of the ECFV – Hypovolemic hyponatremia . Features of Hypovolemia are seen in this patient in the form of dehydration and hypotension. Hyponatremia is defined as a plasma Na+ < 135Mm Lab report here shows that. (Na = 110) Non-renal causes of hypovolemic hyponatremia – Urine Na < 20 Renal causes of hypovolemic hyponatremia – Urine Na > 20 This patient has Urine Na of 50 → Renal cause Amongst the differentials of renal causes, this patient likely has Cerebral wasting syndrome (H/0 subarachnoid haemorrhage as an association ) Cerebral salt wasting : Rare cause of hypovolemic hyponatremia Inappropriate natriuresis Association with intracranial diseases like Subarachnoid haemorrhage Traumatic brain injury Craniotomy Encephalitis Meningitis Typically respond to aggressive Na+-Cl– repletion

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. SIADH is a cause of euvolemic hyponatremia and will have hypouricemia. This Patient is hypovolemic with normal uric acid levels. Hence this is not the correct option. Option: C. Dilutional hyponatremia will present with signs of hypervolemia and not hypovolemia. Hence this is incorrect option Option: D. It is a cause of euvolemic hyponatremia.

Extraedge:

Thiazides d o not inhibit the renal concentrating mechanism Loop diuretics blunt the renal concentrating mechanism

questions.text: A 28 year old female athlete presents to the medicine OPD for a fitness certificate to participate in a marathon. On evaluation, She was found to have a serum sodium level of 122 meq/l. Her further lab investigations are given below: Serum osmolality 265 mosm/kg Urine osmolality – 60 mosm/kg Urine Na -22meq/l RBS-102mg/dl Serum uric acid-5 mg/dl S creatinine-0.7mg/dl TSH-2. 5 mIU/L What is the cause for hyponatremia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Psychogenic polydipsia Patient has a serum osmolality of 265 mOsm/kg → Hypotonic hyponatremia Urine osmolality of 60 mOsm/kg → Very dilute urine A low urine osmolality < 800 → DI A very low osmolality < 100 – 200 Polydipsia Beer potomania TURP syndrome DI is divided into four different types based on the aetiology The second type of DI is → Primary polydipsia Primary polydipsia Due to suppression of AVP secretion by excessive intake of fluids. Types → Three Dipsogenic DI → Excessive fluid intake appears to be caused by inappropriate thirst. (No mention of thirst in this patient) Psychogenic polydipsia → Not associated with thirst Iatrogenic polydipsia → Due to an increase in water intake motivated by a belief in its health benefits No mention of Beer intake / No mention of TURP procedure. No mention of thirst → Hence Psychogenic polydipsia likely ( Option A)

Highyeild:

Psychogenic polydipsia → Feature of psychosis or OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder) Relationships of the rise in plasma AVP to the rise in plasma and urine osmolarity are both normal in primary polydipsia Infusion of hypertonic saline increases the level of circulating Copeptin, a peptide co-secreted with AVP → Polydipsia (Different from central DI)

Extraedge:

Beer potomania (Low solute intake) Occurs in alcoholics whose sole nutrient is beer Beer is very low in protein and salt content (1–2 mM of Na) Low solute intake typically present with a very low urine osmolality <100–200 mOsm/kg Urine Na+ < 10 – 20 mM

questions.text: A 45 year old patient has presented with chronic hyponatremia. His serum sodium is 124 meq/l. Further evaluation revealed the cause as SIADH. As a part of his treatment, he is to be started on water restriction. His lab reports are as follows: Serum Na/K+/Cl 124/3. 9/104 Serum osmolarity-270 mmol/l Urinary sodium -42 meq/l Urine potassium -20 meq/l What is the recommended water restriction volume in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Fluid restriction is not indicated in chronic hyponatremia

questions.explanation:
Solution:

< 1 litre per day The scenario is of SIADH-induced chronic hyponatremia. Water deprivation can be very difficult for patients with SIADH to tolerate, given that their thirst is also inappropriately stimulated. Calculation of urinary electrolyte-free water clearance is required to estimate daily, ongoing loss of free water which should be replenished daily. The urine-to-plasma electrolyte ratio ( urinary [Na+] + [K+]/plasma [Na+]) can be exploited as a quick indicator of electrolyte-free water excretion Ratio of >1 → Water restriction → <500ml/day Ratio of 1 → Water restriction → 500–700 mL/d Ratio of < 1 → Water restriction → < 1 L/ day In this patient the ratio = 42 + 20 /124 = 62 / 124 = 0.5 Hence water restriction to be done is in this patient < 1L / day ( Option C )

questions.text: A 38 year old male weighing 70 kg has presented with chronic hyponatremia with serum sodium of 120 meq/l. What is the rate of infusion of 3% NaCl required for sodium correction in this patient over 48 hours?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

25 ml/hr The volume of 3% naCl required can be estimated through the following steps STEP 1-Calculation of the Sodium required (i.e. the sodium deficit) Na required =TBWx(desired sodium- Actual sodium) -0.6 x 70 x (135-120) =630mmol STEP 2-Calculation of volume Volume(liter)= Na required/513 =630/513 =1.228 litres =1228ml STEP 3- Calculate rate This 1228 ml is to be given over 48 hours le rate of infusion is 1228/48=25.58ml/hr Therefore the correct answer among the options is 25ml/hr

Highyeild:

Plasma Na+ concentration should be monitored every 2–4 h

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option a,c,d are wrong numerical values.

Extraedge:

3% NS bolus is more effective than infusion Type of respiratory failure seen: Hypercapnic respiratory failure

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient admitted for LRTI has developed hyponatremia. His serum sodium Workup for the same revealed the cause to be SIADH. He is started on water restriction but the response is inadequate and he is subsequently started on a vasopressin antagonist. Which among the following AVP antagonists cannot be given by oral route?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conivaptan Patients of hyponatremia in whom therapy with fluid restriction, potassium replacement, and/or increased fluid intake fails may merit pharmacological treatment. AVP antagonists (Vaptans) are highly effective in SIADH Hypervolemic hyponatremia AVP preserves Blood pressure via vascular and baroreceptor V1A receptors Increases water reabsorption via renal V2 receptors Tolvaptan is the only oral v aptan to be approved Antagonizes the V2 AVP receptor, thereby preventing water reabsorption. → Aquaretic effects (augmentation of free water clearance) Conivaptan The only intravenous vaptan Mixed V1A/V2 antagonist (Option B is correct)

Highyeild:

While on therapy with vaptans Liberalization of fluid restriction (>2 L/d) Close monitoring of plasma Na levels. Tolvaptan is most appropriate for the management of SIADH.

Extraedge:

Chronic tolvaptan therapy → Abnormalities in liver function tests Hence duration of treatment < 1 – 2 months Conivaptan therapy → Modest risk of hypotension due to V1A receptor inhibition

questions.text: A 52 year old male is diagnosed as a case of SIADH secondary to bacterial pneumonia. He is found to have serum sodium of 118 meq/l. He is started on fluid restriction and subsequently tolvaptan therapy. Tolvaptan should not be given for >1 month due to which of the following side effects
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hepatotoxicity AVP antagonists (Vaptans) are highly effective in SIADH Hypervolemic hyponatremia Tolvaptan is the only oral v aptan to be approved It is most appropriate for the management of SIADH. Antagonizes the V2 AVP receptor, thereby preventing water reabsorption

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Tolvaptan does not cause nephrotoxicity Option: B . Tolvaptan is not known to cause ototoxicity.

Extraedge:

Chronic tolvaptan therapy à Abnormalities in liver function tests Hence the duration of treatment < 1 – 2 months

questions.text: A 56 year old male is admitted with legionella pneumonia. On day 3 of admission, he went into an altered sensorium. Serum sodium is found to be 116 meq/l. All the following features favour SIADH as the cause for hyponatremia EXCEPT?

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of nausea, adrenal dysfunction and hypothyroidism

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urine osmolality <100 mosm/L SIADH involves the continued secretion or action of arginine vasopressin (AVP) despite normal or increased plasma volume. The resulting impairment of water secretion and consequent water retention produces hyponatremia (ie, serum Na+ < 135 mmol/L) with concomitant hypo-osmolality (serum osmolality < 280 mOsm/kg) and high urine osmolality that are the hallmark of SIADH. Urine sodium is >20 meq/l SIADH is diagnosed by the following Hypo-osmotic hyponatremia Urine osmolality >100 mosm/L Euvolemia Absence of conditions which stimulate ADH secretion which include volume contraction, nausea, adrenal dysfunction and hypothyroidism

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. SIADH is a true hypo-osmotic hyponatremia and presents with a low serum osmolality Option: C. SIADH is an example of euvolemic hyponatremia Option: D. Other causes which stimulate ADH secretion like nausea, hypothyroidism, adrenal dysfunction must be ruled out prior to making diagnosis of SIADH

questions.text: Match the following types of hyponatremia and their causes A. Euvolemic hyponatremia 1. Multiple myeloma B. Hypervolemic hyponatremia 2. Nephrotic syndrome C. Hypovolemic Hyponatremia 3. Hypothyroidism D. Pseudohyponatremia 4. Ketonuria Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-3 B-2 C-4 D-1 Euvolemic hyponatremia implies normal sodium stores and a total body excess of free water. Examples are Glucocorticoid deficiency Hypothyroidism SIADH Hypovolemic hyponatremia - The total body water and sodium content are decreased and the relative decrease in total body sodium is greater than the decrease in total body water. Examples are Osmotic diuresis, Cerebral salt wasting syndrome GI losses -vomiting, diarrhoea Diuretic excess Hypervolemic hyponatremia - when sodium stores increase inappropriately along with an increase in total body water. Examples are a) Renal causes such as acute or chronic renal failure (when dysfunctional kidneys are unable to excrete the ingested sodium) (It also may occur in response to states of decreased effective intravascular volume) Pseudohyponatremia is an uncommonly encountered laboratory abnormality defined by a spuriously low serum sodium concentration of less than 135 mEq/L in the setting of normal serum osmolality. The finding is an artefact that results from the way a blood sample is processed for serum sodium measurement. Caused by Administration of mannitol Multiple myeloma, Hypertriglyceridemia etc.
